Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Understanding of HDA Process: One-Step Conversion of Lignocellulosic Biomass to Furan-Based Precursors for Drop-in Liquid Fuel

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Pan, Xuejun
Proposal Number: 1236562
Institution: University of Wisconsin-Madison
Title: Fundamental Understanding of HDA Process: One-Step Conversion of Lignocellulosic Biomass to Furan-Based Precursors for Drop-in Liquid Fuel

This project is to fundamentally understand an innovative process (HDA: hydrolysis- dehydration-aldol condensation) for producing ?drop-in? biofuel from lignocellulosic biomass. The process directly converts cellulose and hemicellulose in the biomass to furan-based precursors for fuel-grade hydrocarbons in one step under mild conditions (120-140Â°C) without prior biomass pretreatment and fractionation. The precursors can be easily converted to fuel- grade hydrocarbons via hydrogenation/dehydration. Specifically, in the presence of acetone as solvent and reactant and halide salt (such as lithium bromide) and mineral acid as catalysts, the biomass undergoes hydrolysis of cellulose and hemicellulose to monosaccharides, dehydration of the monosaccharides to furfural and hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), and aldol-condensation of HMF and furfural with acetone, and ends up with the formation of furan-based precursors with chain length of C6?C21. Meanwhile, lignin in the biomass is extracted with high purity, low molecular weight, and good reactivity, showing great potential in lignin co-products development. The unreacted acetone and catalysts can be recycled and reused.

The specific objectives of this project are (1) to further optimize the HDA process to improve the conversion yield and selectivity of the furan-based oxygenate precursors and to establish process mass balance; (2) to elucidate the reaction pathways of cell-wall components (cellulose and hemicellulose) and to fundamentally understand the HDA process; (3) to characterize chemical, physical and thermal properties of the extracted HDA lignin.

In addition to innovative research activities, this project also emphasizes on high-quality education, development and dissemination of new knowledge, and outreach activities. The success of proposed process would provide an alternative and innovative approach for producing drop-in liquid fuel from lignocellulosic biomass, such as agricultural crop residues (corn stover), energy crop (switchgrass), and forest biomass (wood). The integrated education plan will target broad range of students. In addition to regular undergraduate and graduate students, special attention will be paid to the students from high school and underrepresented groups by encouraging them participating summer projects on bioenergy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was to demonstrate and fundamentally understand an innovative process (HDA) for producing “drop-in” hydrocarbon biofuel from lignocellulosic biomass. The following are the major outcomes and findings of this project.

The HDA process uses acetone-lithium bromide (LiBr) as reaction medium to convert lignocellulosic biomass to furan-based precursors for hydrocarbon fuels in one step under mild conditions (120-140°C) without prior pretreatment and fractionation of the feedstock biomass. Specifically, in the acetone-LiBr system with small amount of mineral acid (such as hydrochloric acid, HCl) as catalyst, cellulose and hemicelluloses in the lignocellulosic biomass undergo hydrolysis to monosaccharides, dehydration of the monosaccharides to furfural (from pentoses) and hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, from hexoses), and aldol-condensation of HMF and furfural with acetone to the furfural- and HMF-acetone adducts (furan-based precursors) with chain length of C5–C21. The resultant precursors can be subsequently converted to hydrocarbons for drop-in fuel via hydrodeoxygenation. Meanwhile, lignin in the biomass is extensively depolymerized and separated as HDA lignin. The unreacted acetone and LiBr can be recycled and reused.

It was found that the acetone-LiBr system has unique properties such as low viscosity, enhanced acidity, excellent ability to swell and dissolve cellulose, and good solvent of depolymerized lignin. These are the major reasons why cellulose and hemicelluloses of the biomass can be dissolved, hydrolyzed and eventually dehydrated into furans and form the furan-acetone adducts as the precursor of biofuel, and lignin is depolymerized and separated from the biomass.

The HDA process is applicable to different types of biomass, including woody and non-woody biomass (such as corn stover, switchgrass, poplar, aspen, and spruce). The recommended reaction conditions are 1-2% HCl in acetone-LiBr, 120-140°C and 2-3 h, dependent on the species of the biomass. The yield of the precursors varies between 70-80% (molar yield based on starting cellulose and hemicelluloses). The separated HDA lignin has high purity (>98%) and low molecular weight (Mw=2,000-3,000 g/mol), and good reactivity. The lignin is expected to have potential in co-products (chemicals, fuel or fuel additives, and materials) development. 

The overall mass balance of the HDA process was established using corn stover as an example. From 100 kg of corn stover (containing 77.1 kg carbohydrates – cellulose and hemicelluloses), approximately 60.1 kg furan-acetone adducts were produced and 12.6 kg HDA lignin was recovered. About 20% of acetone was consumed as a reactant in the process, and 80% of unreacted acetone was recovered by evaporation. Most of LiBr (99%) was recovered by liquid-liquid extraction. 

To understand the mechanism of lignin depolymerization, native lignin in biomass, lignin model compounds, and technical lignins from paper industry and biorefineries were treated in acidic lithium bromide trihydrate. First, it was demonstrated that the native lignin in lignocellulosic biomass was easily depolymerized in acidic lithium bromide trihydrate under mild conditions (e.g. in 60 % LiBr with 40 mM HCl at 110 °C). Six types of biomass, including hardwood, softwood, and herbaceous biomass, were treated in acidic lithium bromide trihydrate, and the isolated lignin fractions were characterized with GPC and NMR. The results indicated that the β-O-4 ether linkages of the native lignin were selectively cleaved, leading to lignin depolymerization. Second, lignin model compound (guaiacylglycerol-β-guaiacyl ether) was used to elucidate the mechanism of the cleavage of the β-O-4 ether bonds. It was verified that both the LiBr trihydrate media and HCl were crucial to the cleavage of the ether bonds via the enol ether pathway initiated by the α-C cationization. It was observed that new C-C bonds were formed, caused by nucleophilic attack of the benzyl carbocation by the electron-rich lignin aromatic rings. Third, when the technical lignins isolated from pulping and biorefining processes were treated in the acidic lithium bromide trihydrate, the residual β-O-4 ether linkages of the lignin were selectively cleaved as well.

The findings of this project have been used in developing teaching materials. They were also disseminated through the presentations at conferences and through the publications. The project covers broad range of fundamental and applied aspects of science and engineering. This provided an ideal platform through which numerous undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, and visiting scholars were trained. Summer biomass and bioenergy workshops were organized for local high school students, which raised the public awareness of importance and potential of biomass and bioeconomy.

This projected demonstrated a unique technology to produce drop-in hydrocarbon fuels from lignocellulosic biomass. The success of the HDA technology would promote the production of drop-in hydrocarbon fuels from lignocellulose. The findings of this project will be helpful for developing cost-effective biomass conversion technologies for next generation biofuels and biobased chemicals. The outcomes of the project could potentially promote/improve the bioeconomy for producing biofuels and chemicals from biomass. The fundamental understanding of LiBr-enhanced cellulose hydrolysis and lignin depolymerization would provide new knowledge about cellulose dissolution, hydrolysis, and conversion and lignin β-O-4 linkage cleavage in the LiBr-acetone system.
